context: Thus, upon calcination in air, the exchanged Cr(III) suffered oxidation to Cr(VI) species. 3.2.5 H2-TPR A TPR experiment was carried out in order to determine the reducibility of chromium in calcined Cr-NaY catalyst (pH 4) and the results are presented in Fig. 5 . The H2-TPR spectrum showed a single broad peak centered at 460°C. According to several authors [43–47] this consumption of hydrogen could be assigned to Cr(VI)→Cr(III) reduction transitions of chromium species on the zeolite surface. This result is confirmed by the sample colour shift from yellow to light green after the TPR experiment. These observations are an additional indication that oxidation of chromium (initially ion-exchanged as Cr3+) to Cr6+ has occurred upon calcination. 3.2.6

llm_generation.summary: In this context, chromium is involved in a chemical process where hydrogen is used to reduce Cr(VI) species back to Cr(III) during a temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiment. The reduction of chromium species is indicated by a color change and the consumption of hydrogen, suggesting a direct chemical interaction. However, there is no mention of homeopathic preparation, making its relevance unclear.
